newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Hong Kong daily says China's opium-war epic a bore.
newsitem.headline: Hong Kong daily says China's opium-war epic a bore.

text.p: China's epic movie of the 19th century Opium War when Britain seized Hong Kong was branded an "opium bore" on Thursday by a leading film critic here.
"The result seems more like a loud cannon blast that disappears into a cloud of smoke," Dennis Eng wrote in the Hong Kong Standard, a Chinese-owned English-language daily.
Eng also said "The Opium War", a US$12 million blockbuster with a cast of 50,000 including 3,000 non-Chinese, was a "one-sided drama" and "bogged down by too many subplots".

This was the first review to appear in Hong Kong media and a spokeswoman for distributors Panasia Films said :"This is only one critic and the movie has not opened to the public yet so this is not a general verdict."

The film, which depicts Britain seizing Hong Kong from the Qing Dynasty's empire after winning a war over opium trade, will be released on Friday ahead of Hong Kong's return to China at midnight on June 30.
Panasia launched the local premiere with twin screenings at the Hong Kong Convention Centre on Wednesday. It was first shown in Beijing.

Governor Chris Patten was not invited to the VIP events where his successor, future leader Tung Chee-hwa, the president of the incoming legislature Rita Fan and the deputy director of China's Hong Kong mission, Zhang Junsheng, mingled with some 1,000 guests.
